Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 33, Heaven of YÄma, Part 19
At that time, the king of geese saw the lord of the gods, Muá¹£itasmá¹›ti, and said:
Welcome!
He made various statements to greet and make offerings. After making offerings, he praised, saying:
Excellent!
The king of the YÄma Heaven is able to practice in this way without negligence. It is extremely rare.
In this foremost place of indulgence, he is able to practice in this way without negligence. This is rare.
There is also something rare:
All the lords of the gods enjoy a hundred times more pleasure in the heavens without negligence. This is extremely rare;
Apart from the causes and conditions of pleasure, it cannot be obtained.
In this way, the Bodhisattva Bhiká¹£u Saá¹ƒbahula, the king of geese, remembered his past life and the sÅ«tra teachings he had once heard from Buddha Åšikhin.
Having recited that sÅ«tra, he said to the heavenly king Muzhoulou Tuo:
Great king, you have obtained good benefits. You are not negligent in practice. In order to hear my voice, you have come here. This is very rare.
You should listen well now. I will speak for you.
As the World-Honored One Shiqi Rulai spoke,
At that time, I was a human king. Hearing the Thus-Come One's speech, I will now speak for you as I originally heard it.
You should listen attentively now and contemplate it well.
There is a Dharma gate called the Practice of Kings' Dharma. Such a Dharma gate can benefit the ká¹£atriya kings who have been sprinkled with the crown prince's consecration.

If a king obtains this Dharma, he will always obtain peace and happiness in the present world, always have benefits, properly protect the country, be able to protect himself, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, be born in the good realms, among the heavenly worlds, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.

What are the deeds that a duly consecrated ká¹£atriya king accomplishes that enable him to always enjoy happiness and benefit in the present world, to properly protect the world, to be greatly wealthy and powerful, to protect his own body, to be praised by good people, and to be reborn in the celestial realms of the Heaven of YÄma as a king of the Heaven of YÄma with great spiritual powers and great wealth and power after the body's collapse and end of life?

Namely, this king fully accomplishes thirty-seven dharmas, enabling him to always enjoy happiness and benefit in the present world, to properly protect the world, to be greatly wealthy and powerful due to protecting the world, to be indestructible by any other kings, to protect his own body, to be praised by good people, and to be reborn in the celestial realms of the Heaven of YÄma as a king of the Heaven of YÄma after the body's collapse and end of life.
What are called the thirty-seven dharmas?
First, the king's military forces are all pure and clean;
Second, he collects taxes according to the law;
Third, he always harbors patience and does not become angry;
Fourth, being impartial in making decisions;
Fifth, always making offerings to elders;
Sixth, following the old ways and giving according to the past;
Seventh, being generous without stinginess;
Eighth, not accepting those who engage in non-dharma;
Ninth, not associating with bad friends;
Tenth, being faithful and not attached to women;
Eleventh, not believing everything one hears;
Twelfth, loving a good reputation and not coveting wealth;
Thirteenth, abandoning wrong views;
Fourteenth, always being generous;
Fifteenth, speaking kindly and pleasantly;
Sixteenth, speaking truthfully;
Seventeenth, not promoting or demoting officials without reason;
Eighteenth, knowing people's good and bad qualities;
Nineteenth, always seeing people at a fixed time;
Twentieth, not sleeping too much;
Twenty-one, always not lazy;
Twenty-two, firm friendship;
Twenty-three, not befriending any unhelpful friends;
Twenty-four, unmoved by anger or joy;
Twenty-five, not greedy for food and drink;
Twenty-six, good mental contemplation;
Twenty-seven, not acting hastily, but calmly;
Twenty-eight, benefiting the world through the Dharma;
Twenty-nine, always practicing the ten wholesome courses of action;
Thirty, believing in causes and conditions;
Thirty-one, always making offerings to the gods;
Thirty-two, properly protecting the country;
Thirty-three, properly protecting one's wife and children;
Thirty-four, always cultivating wisdom;
Thirty-five, not delighting in objects;
Thirty-six, not allowing evil people to reside within one's country;
Thirty-seven, according with the Dharma in granting salaries and positions to all the people.
These are called the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment.

If one accomplishes these thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, one is called a crowned and consecrated ká¹£atriya king. In this life, one always experiences happiness and benefit, is greatly wealthy and joyful, has much wealth and treasures, is able to protect the country and oneself, is praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, is reborn in a good realm, in the heavens, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
This is due to the good causes and conditions of these thirty-seven factors.
What is meant by the purity of the king's army?
It means having a good mind and benefiting others.
When dealing with disputes, one resolves matters according to the Dharma, does not violate the Dharma, and properly protects according to the Dharma, not going against the original commitment.
One loyally admonishes the ruler, the ruler acts for the benefit of others, follows and accomplishes good deeds, and protects the country according to the Dharma.
The teachings one establishes benefit according to one's capacity, and one simply arouses an upright mind, not troubling others.
Relying on the Dharma and the leader, not just fearing punishment.
The mind is free from greed and arrogance.

In all dharmas, one is in accord and not in opposition, practicing in accordance with the Dharma for the future, fearing birth and death, believing in the fruits of karma, abandoning the three evil karmas, not delighting in much desire, not enjoying punishment, and the right mind being undisturbed.
In this way, both oneself and others can be liberated, and one can benefit the king.
If it is like this, this is the king's army.

Such an army is in accord with the king, and therefore it causes the king to always obtain peace and happiness in the present world, always having benefits, able to protect the country and able to protect oneself, praised by good people, the body perishes and the life ends, born in the good realms, in the heavens, becoming the king of the YÄma Heaven.
Because all the armies are pure, therefore it causes the king to not give rise to evil thoughts, due to the causes of good karma.

The king should also practice the second Dharma, which is to be in accord with the characteristics and always beneficial in the present world, protecting the country and himself, praised by good people, and after the body's disintegration and death, being reborn in the good realms, the heavenly world, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
What is the second?
It is to receive taxes according to the Dharma for clothing and food.
What is meant by according to the Dharma?
At all times, in all countries, cities, villages, towns, or places where people gather, one should take according to the old rules and principles.

If the country is destroyed or there is a famine, the king should not impose taxes. When taking, he should do so reasonably, without oppression or punishment, according to the old standards, using the same weights and measures as before.
In this way, accepting and taking in accordance with the Dharma, without oppression, punishment, invasion, or seizure, such a king is compassionate to all beings.

If the king accepts in this way in accordance with the Dharma, due to the causes and conditions of merit, in the present world he will always experience happiness and benefit, be able to protect the country and himself, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, he will be born in the heavens, becoming the king of the YÄma Heaven.
This is due to the causes and conditions of good karma of always accepting taxes in accordance with the Dharma.

'Moreover, there is a third principle that a duly anointed ká¹£atriya king should diligently practice, which, when accomplished and conformed to, will not oppress the country and bring benefit in both the present and future lives.
What is the third?
It is called always being patient and not angry.
The mind should think like this:
Whatever causes and conditions lead me to anger, I will abandon all such causes and conditions.
Although the body is free, seeing the faults of others, do not criticize or correct them.
For those who have faults among the ministers, relatives, and servants, do not impose heavy punishments.
For those who are enemies, or those who are close and good, do not speak of their faults or their evil.
If one gives rise to an angry mind towards the military, then contemplate patience;
By contemplating patience, the angry mind will then be extinguished.
Speak beautiful words with the mouth, and speak different words, causing the military to be neither worried nor afraid.
Always like this, patient at all times in all dharmas, the essence of patience is real, not due to conditions. Do not be angry like this, do not be resentful like this.

If the king thus harbors patience in his mind, due to the causes and conditions of merit, in the present world he will always obtain peace and happiness, always have benefits, be able to protect the country and protect himself, be praised by good people, and when his body perishes and his life ends, he will be reborn in a good realm, in the heavens of the YÄma Heaven as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
It is because he is able to always harbor patience and good karma in the human realm.

'Moreover, there is a fourth principle that the duly anointed ká¹£atriya king should diligently practice, which, when accomplished and conformed to, brings benefit in both the present and future worlds.
What is the fourth?
Namely, to be impartial in judging affairs.

With a good mind and intention, the king is like a parent to all the people. He does not do so because of wealth, use, relatives, kindness, friends, or noble power. He does not use any of these causes and conditions. He judges affairs according to the Dharma, without partiality or bias.
In disputes, they treat enemies and friends equally, speak beneficial words, and speak truthfully.

If the king thus impartially decides cases, due to the causes and conditions of merit, in the present world he will always obtain peace and happiness, always have benefits, not lose his country, not lose his reputation, all the military forces will have no punishment, he will be able to protect the country, not fear other discussions, other kings will not surpass him, he will be king for a long time, rule the country, be able to protect himself, be praised by good people, at the end of life and body, be born in the good realms, in the heavens, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
Because of the good causes and conditions of impartially deciding cases with a sincere mind.

Moreover, there is a fifth principle that the duly anointed ká¹£atriya king should diligently practice, which, when accomplished and conformed to, brings benefit in both the present and future lives, and so forth, up to reaching nirvÄá¹‡a.
What is the fifth?
It is called always making offerings to elders.
Who are the elders?

The elders are those who see things as they truly are, uphold the precepts, have wisdom and practice, benefit sentient beings, always perform good deeds, and are always tranquil in body, speech, and mind, with pure minds causing others to accumulate blessings.
Such elders should be befriended by the king.
Having befriended them, he should listen to the Dharma, hear the Dharma, always go to make offerings, accept what they say, and accept their teachings.
He should uphold what they say and practice as they say.

Due to the merit of always making offerings to the elders, in the present life he will always experience peace and happiness, always have benefits, be able to protect the country and his own body, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, be born in the heavens, becoming the king of the YÄma Heaven.
This is due to the cause and condition of the good karma of always making offerings to the elders.
The king should also cultivate the sixth principle, which is to follow the old and give according to the past.
What is the sixth?
It means to follow the old and give according to the past.

If the father gave in the past, or the grandfather gave in the past, or if the ancestors gave in the past, whether it be land, gold, silver, or other things, the enthroned king should follow with an untainted mind, a pure mind, and joyfully love that principle.
In this way, following the old, praising goodness, and teaching others to give.

If the king is like this, following the past and giving, the causes and conditions of merit will enable him to always have peace and benefit in the present world, to protect the country and his own body, to be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, to be born in the heavens, in the realm of the YÄma Heaven, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
It is because of always following the old and giving according to the past, due to the causes and conditions of good karma.
The king should also cultivate the seventh principle, which is to be generous and not stingy.
What does this mean?

Generosity means giving at all times, giving everything, giving of all kinds, giving at all times, benefiting all, benefiting and bringing peace to all, always thinking of those in the realms of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals who suffer from hunger, thirst, and other afflictions.
When giving, one should wish that these beings in the three evil realms may be quickly liberated and reborn in the human or heavenly realms.
If the king can do this, he will obtain the rewards of the present world.
What are the rewards of the present world?
They are fame and praise;
when encountering difficulties, servants and soldiers will not abandon him;

People from other countries will always come to make offerings, and others, seeing this, will not be able to destroy it. All enemies will not be able to find even the slightest opportunity. One will always be victorious over others.
Thus, by giving, one obtains the fruits of the present world.

If giving in this way to a non-field of merit still brings such fruits of the present world, how much more so for giving to a field of merit with perfect objects and thoughts, always closing the evil paths and always experiencing the fruits of happiness. One gives in this way with immeasurable kinds of giving.
What is immeasurable?
It refers to the giving of Dharma, the giving of material things, and the giving of fearlessness.

The king gives in this way with various kinds of giving. If one gives to Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, due to the causes and conditions of the merit of such giving, in the present world one will always experience peace and joy, always have benefits, be able to protect the country and protect oneself, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, be born in the heavens, in the realm of the YÄma Heaven King.
Because of the causes and conditions of the good karma of giving.

'Moreover, there is an eighth principle that the duly consecrated ká¹£atriya king should diligently abandon, which, when accomplished and practiced, brings benefit in both the present and future lives.
What is the eighth?
Namely, not harboring those who engage in unrighteous conduct, not allowing them to remain in the country.
Because the ká¹£atriya king himself practices in accordance with the Dharma, he therefore does not harbor those who engage in unrighteous conduct, not allowing them to dwell in the country.
Who are those called those who engage in unrighteous conduct?
Namely, there are people who use various means to rob others of their possessions, or who strike others' throats to make them faint and then take their possessions.
Or who give them bad medicine, causing them to lose consciousness and then take their possessions.ğŸ”½Or who devise schemes to steal others' possessions.
Or who secretly steal others' possessions.
Or who use various means to take others' possessions on roads or in marketplaces.
Or who buy genuine goods and sell them as fake, deceiving others in various ways to take their possessions.
Or there may be people who are deceitful and unjust, who oppress the good and promote the evil, who advance the wrong and relegate the right, who falsely accuse the virtuous and support the unworthy.
Some may have wrong views, some may have nihilistic views.
Some may cruelly kill sentient beings, hoping to attain liberation.
If it is an external path's observance day, they may slaughter sheep and other animals in a great assembly, hoping for merit and virtue.
Some may castrate sentient beings, making them unable to be men.
Some may engage in sexual acts with men.
Some may be unable to make offerings to their parents and teachers.
Such people are not allowed to reside in the country.
Why is this?
If they share the same country, it will cause the minds of the good people to be corrupted and to imitate each other.
Because they reside together, the good people will be corrupted, causing the king to lose power and his superior power.
It will rain at the wrong time and not rain when it should.
When the five grains are ripe, the five grains will not ripen.
All countries are destroyed due to the faults of evil people.
For this reason, do not allow evil people to reside in the country.
For this reason, do not accept all those who practice non-dharma, do not allow them to reside in the country;
Accept those who practice in accordance with the Dharma, and let them reside in the country.

Because of accepting those who practice the Dharma, rain falls in a timely manner, the sun shines in accordance with the season, therefore the five grains ripen well in a timely manner, the country is not destroyed, free from fear, and no worries arise.

All the beneficial matters in all countries are due to the power of the causal conditions of accepting those who practice the Dharma, which can sever all the suffering and distress of birth and death, and allow those with blessings to reside in their own country.
Because of being close to such people with blessings and virtue, and because of practicing the Dharma.
The foremost pure conduct is called abiding in peace.

People with blessings and virtue are close to people with blessings and virtue, and those who practice in accordance with the Dharma. Therefore, all wise kings are close to those who practice the Dharma and let them reside in the country.

If the king does not include such unlawful people, due to the causes and conditions of this merit, he will always experience happiness and benefit in the present life, be able to protect the country and himself, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, be reborn in the heavens as a king of the YÄma Heaven.
Because of the causes of good karma of not including unlawful people.
There is a ninth principle that a duly consecrated ká¹£atriya king should diligently abandon, and by accomplishing it, he will benefit in both the present and future lives.
What is the ninth?
It is called not associating with bad friends.
Bad friends are evil friends. There are eight kinds of evil friends that all kings should abandon.
What are the eight?
First, the view of annihilation. There are people who think like this:
There is no karma, no giving, no this world, no other world.
This is the first evil friend.
Moreover, the second evil friend is someone who thinks like this:
All women can be engaged with at the right time without breaking celibacy.
Moreover, the third evil friend is someone who thinks like this:
If one burns [oneself], one attains great merit.
If one gives to sentient beings, there is no merit.
Moreover, the fourth evil friend is someone who thinks like this:
As long as one is alive before death, one is called a person.
After the body dies, all good and bad karma are lost, like clouds blown away by the wind, and there is nothing more to accumulate. Sentient beings are like this, without sin or merit.
Moreover, the fifth evil friend is someone who always teaches others to destroy their parents and also does not allow them to make offerings to their elders.
Furthermore, the sixth kind of bad friend is someone who says that killing is good;
that by killing old people, blind people, sick people, or long-term patients, and depriving them of life, one can be reborn in a happy place.
Furthermore, the seventh kind of bad friend is someone who thinks like this:

By jumping off a cliff, burning one's body, starving to death, or roasting one's body in five places, if one dies like this, one will obtain immeasurable blessings and be reborn in the heavens later, with immeasurable retinue and immeasurable celestial maidens making offerings.
Furthermore, the eighth kind of bad friend is someone who thinks like this:
Everything is due to fate, not the fruits of karma.
These eight kinds of bad friends are not allowed to stay in the country, and one should not even look at them with one's eyes.
Only those who include all true words are people who listen to the true Dharma from such a person, and after hearing it, accept it, uphold it, and practice it.

If the king does not associate with any unwholesome companions in this way, due to the causes and conditions of merit, he will always obtain happiness and benefit in the present world, be able to protect the country and protect himself, be praised by good people, and after the body perishes and life ends, he will be born in the good realms, in the heavens of the Heaven of YÄma.
It is because of the causes and conditions of good karma from not associating with unwholesome companions.

Moreover, there is a tenth principle that a duly installed ká¹£atriya king should diligently abandon, and by accomplishing it, he will obtain benefits in both the present and future lives.ğŸ”½What is the tenth? It refers to a principle that should be abandoned.
What principle should be abandoned?
It refers to women.
A wise person does not submit to women. All worldly people who submit to women are the most vulgar in the world.
If ordinary people are subject to women, they are still vulgar and contemptible, let alone a king who is the foremost among people.
All women can destroy people, all countries, all people, and all kings are destroyed by women.
Because of greed, they can cause kings and others to lose all benefits, can take away their possessions, cause them to engage in wrongdoing, and prevent them from giving in charity.
Because of greed, they can cause kings and others to be all lazy.
Because of desire, they always stay close and never leave, causing men to lose their own benefits.
Women are like hail, able to destroy good sprouts.
All women enjoy destructive speech and are a storehouse of arrogance and jealousy.
Those subject to women act like women.
Those subject to women lose their countries as well.
Therefore, one should not be bound to women. If one is bound to women, one becomes vulgar, because the nature of women is vulgar and evil.
Being under the control of a woman is also contemptible.
Being under the control of a woman leads to the loss of all the Dharma.
Being under the control of a woman always leads to suffering.
If one is under the control of a woman, good people will abandon him.
Because of the faults of desire, such a person is deceived by women.
All women are deceitful and domineering towards weak people, because that is their nature. They do not know gratitude and can bring harm. They are very greedy, jealous, and envious.
Women are like this, all untrustworthy.

If one is under the control of a woman, that person will be the most contemptible of all people in cities and villages, let alone a king, whose loss will be even greater. Therefore, one should not be under the control of a woman.

If the king fears the faults of women in this way, due to the causes and conditions of merit, in the present world he will always obtain peace and joy, always have benefits, be able to protect the country and protect himself, be praised by good people, and when his body perishes and his life ends, he will be born in a good realm, in the heavens of the YÄma Heaven as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
Because of abandoning the good karma of women.
'Again, there is one more principle for the ká¹£atriya king, which is the eleventh. He should diligently practice and accomplish it, benefiting both the present and future worlds.
The eleventh is: Do not believe everything you hear.
The minds of all people in the world are not the same, they destroy each other, and their nature delights in destruction.
When something is made, they can destroy it. When it is completed, they can destroy it.
Because their inherent nature is itself defiled, they destroy it. They always delight in quarreling, so they destroy each other.
Because they are close relatives, they destroy each other.
The destruction of their own bodies is due to the faults of the country, and therefore they are destroyed.
Because of their own self-importance, they destroy each other.
They speak to each other in the darkness, each claiming their own understanding, and therefore they destroy each other.
Wishing to be victorious themselves and to defeat others, they destroy each other.
The king does not believe all such words, because they are contrary to reason and contradict each other.
Because they come from evil minds in succession, and because they speak like this out of love for their own faction.
Those who have been instructed before, those who have been entrusted before, those who have had kindness before, and those who have had enmity before, destroy each other and come to tell the king.
These are the causes and conditions mentioned before, and they speak like this because they hate each other.
The king does not believe universally, and therefore the country is not destroyed.
Such a king has a good nature, is not disobedient or confused, is reasonable in his anger, and does not get angry for no reason. He does not believe in divisive speech.

That king himself has such virtues, does not believe in others, is happy in his own mind, has little anger, and all beings love the king. He thinks well, follows the Dharma, his mind is upright, and he controls much territory.

If the king does not believe in everything in this way, due to the causes and conditions of his virtues, he will always have peace and benefit in the present world, will be able to protect the country and himself, will be praised by good people, and when his body perishes and his life ends, he will be born in a good realm, in the heavens of the Heaven of YÄma.
Because of the causes of good karma of not believing in everything.
'There is another principle for ká¹£atriya kings, the twelfth, which they should diligently practice, accomplish, and be in accord with, for the benefit of both the present and future lives.
Twelfth, loving a good reputation, not coveting wealth and goods.

Because the king's mind does not covet wealth and goods, he does not clench his fists, does not move his eyebrows and face, does not glare with angry eyes, does not speak harsh words, his mind is never angry without reason, and his mind is also never joyful without reason, his mind is firm.
If the king is like this, he will obtain a good reputation and also obtain wealth and goods.
Having obtained this, he is not greatly delighted in the midst of wealth and goods.
Because of obtaining a good reputation, his mind of superior delight, the king's law is unobstructed, all people love him, and enemies cannot take advantage of him.
Because of having much wealth and goods.
Moreover, there are ten more causes and conditions for obtaining a beautiful reputation. What are the ten?
First, beautiful speech;
second, being able to give;
third, being discerning; fourth, people from other countries come to visit;
fifth, if one approaches him, one obtains peace and joy;
sixth, giving to the left and right in a timely manner;
Seventh, respecting and venerating elders, providing for their needs, supporting the virtuous, and rescuing the orphaned and helpless;
Eighth, pure conduct;
Ninth, a good heart, not troubling others;
Tenth, right views, not giving rise to wrong views.
Obtaining these ten dharmas, practicing such dharmas, and further teaching others to practice such dharmas.
By practicing in this way and obtaining these dharmas, one attains a good reputation.

If the king loves a good reputation like this and is not greedy for wealth, due to the causes and conditions of merit, in the present world he will always experience happiness and benefit, will follow the practice of the Dharma, will be unconquerable by others, and those who approach him will attain happiness.

That person will be a king among humans for a long time, will be able to protect the country and his own body, will be praised by the virtuous, and when his body perishes and his life ends, he will be born in the celestial realm of the Heaven of YÄma as the king of the Heaven of YÄma.
It is because of the good karma of loving a good reputation and not being greedy for wealth.
The king of the ká¹£atriyas has a thirteenth rule that he should diligently abandon and accomplish in order to benefit both the present and future lives.ğŸ”½
The king should also abandon the thirteenth fault, which is to abandon wrong views.
Wrong views are the basis of all sentient beings' lack of peace and security.
This inverted view does not give rise to faith in any causes and conditions.
The king should abandon those places of disbelief, hatred, and slander.
If the king does not abandon them, he will engage in wrong views, be hated by all, not be trusted by anyone, and no one will follow him.
Because no one follows him, everyone will abandon him. When he encounters decline and distress, the gods who rely on the Dharma will all abandon him;
once the gods have abandoned him, he will be unable to do anything.

Therefore, the king should abandon wrong views. If the king has right views and is not deluded in this way, due to the causes and conditions of merit, in the present world he will always experience happiness, always have benefits, be able to protect the country and protect himself, be praised by good people, do what is beneficial at all times, be worshipped by all people, be loved by all people, and the gods who follow the Dharma will always be by his side. All the people in the country will act according to the king's intentions, and all his thoughts and intentions will be fulfilled.

The king's mind and nature are not confused, and he will rule the country for a long time, peacefully and without trouble. When the body perishes and life ends, he will be born in the good realms, in the heavenly world, as the king of the YÄma Heaven.
This is due to the causes and conditions of good karma from abandoning wrong views.
'There is another principle for ká¹£atriya kings, the fourteenth, which, when accomplished and practiced, brings benefits in both the present and future lives.
The fourteenth is the worldly dharmas, the supramundane dharmas, and the fundamental dharmas of the king, namely generosity.

If the king or his ministers are able to practice generosity, all the people of the country will respect and love him, and will not abandon him. They will give rise to reverence and will not abandon his country to go to other lands.
If the people of other countries, because the king is able to give, come together with their wives and children and their armies, all of them will come and submit to the king.
Because many people come, it causes the people of the king's country to increase even more, and the other countries are unable to destroy them.
Because there are many people, no one is able to destroy them.
Such generosity is the worldly generosity, the foremost comfort in the world.
Moreover, there is another supramundane generosity, the best generosity. If a person practices generosity, he is embraced by the gods and has great power and great majestic virtue.
Giving to Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and poor people, adorns the future and brings good complexion in the present.
Why is this?
Because the mind is pure, the food is pure;
Because the food is pure, the complexion is pure;
Because the complexion is pure, one is upright and pleasing.
These are all the power of giving, and there is also the Dharma that brings immediate results.
What is the immediate result?

It is called giving, the mind is without arrogance, free from greed and jealousy, believing in causes and conditions, believing in causes, believing in retribution, believing in the future world, making offerings to elders, the mind is gentle, the right thought is mindfulness, abandoning various things, gathering the causes of great wealth, gathering free from stinginess and jealousy, believing in the field of blessings, the merits of the field of blessings, and the seeds of the field of blessings.
